Description: Limestone head from a life-size male statue, probably a representation of the god Apollo or a deity represented with this imagery. The back of the head is missing, as is the top of the forehead.
Curator's comments: This head was described as 'Venus' in the original catalogue and then by Pryce as a portrait of Berenike I because of the style of the hair which he said was a 'fine example of the metallic style of the later years of Ptolemy I'. The statue is actually male and of a deity, represented with the typical Hellenistic attributes of Apollo. See Senff (1993, 66-8) for a modern discussion of the style and iconography, and passim for the sanctuary of Apollo-Reshef. According to Hermary, the corkscrew curls on this head, though sometimes linked to Egyptianising influences found within Ptolemaic art (and ultimately deriving from Cyrene), actual belong in a tradition of representations of Apollo in Cyprus established since the early Cypro-Classical periods (and seen on the bronze Chatsworth Apollo, and the limestone 'Zeus of Malloura') (Hermary 2009, with refs). Bibliography: Hermary A. 2009. 'Un Apollon chypriote aux boucles'. In. D. Michaelides, V. Kassianidou and R.S. Merrillees (eds), Egypt and Cyprus in Antiquity (Oxford; Oakville: Oxbow), 136-43. Senff R. 1993. Das Apolloheiligtum von Idalion. Architektur und Statuenausstattung eines zyprischen Heiligstum. SIMA XCIV (Jonsered: P. Åström).
